title: 111_s3838
content: Appropriation of funds for final settlement of claims from Black Farmers Discrimination Litigation. The curr_chunk defines "Pigford claim" and "Settlement Agreement" related to the resolution of claims from the Black Farmers Discrimination Litigation. The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 appropriates $1,150,000,000 to the Secretary of Agriculture for the Settlement Agreement, in addition to $100,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation. These funds are available only after the Corporation funds are fully obligated. The Settlement Agreement requires approval for the $100,000,000 Commodity Credit Corporation funds. If not approved, these funds will be the sole funding for Pigford claims. The use of appropriated funds is subject to the Settlement Agreement terms. Unused funds will be returned to the Treasury if not obligated for the Agreement. The section discusses the availability of funds for settlement agreements related to the Black Farmers Discrimination Litigation and clarifies that it does not require anyone to enter into the agreements or create a basis for a Pigford claim. Amendments are made to the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 to reflect these changes. Amendments are made to the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008, including changes to subsections (e), (f), (g), and (i) regarding funding for settlement agreements related to the Black Farmers Discrimination Litigation. Relief for discrimination in a credit program of the Department of Agriculture under the Equal Credit Opportunity Act is addressed in Section 2. The term "eligible complaint" refers to a written complaint that is not employment related, filed with the Department of Agriculture after December 31, 1997, and before 2 years after the alleged violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act or the date of the enactment of this Act, and the complainant was not a party to the consent decree in the case entitled "Pigford v. Glickman". The term "eligible complaint" refers to a written complaint filed with the Department of Agriculture after December 31, 1997, and before 2 years after the alleged violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. The complaint must not be employment related and the complainant must not have been a party to the consent decree in the case entitled "Pigford v. Glickman". The filing period is defined as the 2-year period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Credit Opportunity Act (15 U.S.C. 1691) allows complainants in a credit program of the Department of Agriculture to file a civil action or request administrative review before the end of the filing period. A civil action can be filed if the complainant has not requested administrative review or if the Secretary fails to issue a determination within 180 days of the request. Administrative review can be requested according to specific guidelines. Under this subsection, a complainant may request a determination on the merits if they have not filed a civil action. They can also request a hearing on the record if they have not filed a civil action, requested a determination on the merits, and the Secretary has not issued such determination within the specified deadline. Additionally, the Secretary has the authority to settle an eligible complaint with a complainant. The Secretary may settle an eligible complaint with a complainant. Requests for administrative review must be in writing and filed according to procedures. If a complainant requests a determination on the merits, the Secretary shall take specific actions unless a civil action is filed or a hearing on the record is requested. The Secretary must investigate and issue a written determination on an eligible complaint within 1 year of the request. If the determination is not issued on time, the Secretary must notify the complainant in writing and specify the period for taking further legal action. The filing period for a civil action or requesting a hearing on the record is tolled from the date of request for determination on the merits until the Secretary issues a final determination. A complainant may be awarded relief under subsection (b) and (e) of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, including actual damages, attorney's fees, and debt relief such as principal or interest write-downs, interest rate reductions, and penalty waivers. The total relief awarded under this section for all claims is capped at $100,000,000, with specific limits for actual damages, costs, and attorney's fees not exceeding $40,000,000, and debt relief not exceeding $60,000,000. Awards under certain clauses are exempt from taxation. The Secretary is appropriated $100,000,000 for relief under subsection (h)(1), not taxable under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
